original_solution_mapping.L1: He sold an average of 16 books per month across all 3 months so he must have sold a total of 3*16 = <<16*3=48>>48 books in those 3 months
original_solution_mapping.L2: He sold 15+16 = <<15+16=31>>31 in January and February
original_solution_mapping.L3: He must have sold 48-31 = <<48-31=17>>17 books in March

original_function_code:
def solve():
    """Index: 1473.
    Returns: the number of books sold in March.
    """
    # L1
    average_books_per_month = 16 # average number of books he sold per month across all three months is 16
    num_months = 3 # across all three months
    total_books_3_months = num_months * average_books_per_month

    # L2
    january_sales = 15 # 15 books in January
    february_sales = 16 # 16 in February
    jan_feb_sales = january_sales + february_sales

    # L3
    march_sales = total_books_3_months - jan_feb_sales

    # FA
    answer = march_sales
    return answer

logical_steps.solution_line_template: He sold an average of {average_books_per_month} books per month across all {num_months} months so he must have sold a total of {num_months}*{average_books_per_month} = <<{average_books_per_month}*{num_months}={total_books_3_months}>>{total_books_3_months} books in those {num_months} months
He sold {january_sales}+{february_sales} = <<{january_sales}+{february_sales}={jan_feb_sales}>>{jan_feb_sales} in January and February
He must have sold {total_books_3_months}-{jan_feb_sales} = <<{total_books_3_months}-{jan_feb_sales}={march_sales}>>{march_sales} books in March

flawed_nl_reconstruction.L1: He sold an average of 16 books per month across all 3 months so he must have sold a total of 3*16 = <<16*3=48>>48 books in those 3 months
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L2: He sold 15+16 = <<15+16=31>>31 in January and February
flawed_nl_reconstruction.L3: He must have sold 48-15 = <<48-15=33>>33 books in March

explanation: Incorrect operand. The variable 'january_sales' (value: 15) was used instead of 'jan_feb_sales' (value: 31).
